entry.title: New Events for Outbound Nota Fiscal
entry.content:
Hi everyone!  

Today, I would like to share with you some impactful insights directly from an SAP Note, which outlines a streamlined approach for sending the events listed in the NF-e Technical Note 2025.002 v1.30, published October 2025. 

You can implement these changes in the outbound invoicing option for Brazil by following the instructions on SAP Note 3692197 and SAP Note 3689265. 

Check out the latest updates and features in our What's New session on the SAP Help Portal: 

  • SAP S/4HANA: New Events for Outbound Nota Fiscal 
  • SAP ERP: New Events for Outbound Nota Fiscal 

The Process 

To send these events, you need to create a specific structure, as described in the "Manual da SEFAZ". You should create the new structure through the SEND_GENERIC_EVENT method from the CL_NFE_CLOUD_NFE_PROCESSOR class. This effectively sends the events using the IS_GENERIC_EVENT parameter, which is essential for declaring the structure. 

You have to name this structure as ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_XXXXXX. You replace the XXXXXX for the number of supported events from the NF-e Technical Note 2025.002 v1.30. For example: ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110.  

In this structure, you'll find control fields and event-specific fields that are mapped directly to the XML event. You have to build the DET_EVENTO structure, which can vary depending on the type of event. The field names differ between the backend system and their appearance in the cloud solution. Check the following example:  

The structure of the event 112110 (Informação de efetivo pagamento integral para liberar crédito presumido do adquirente) is denoted as ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110. This structure has the following string fields and their equivalent in the cloud solution, following the rules of name conversion: 

  • ATTR_VERSAO -> converted to a__versao to create the XML (you can check the rule to create XML attributes instead of elements in SAP Note 3692197) 
  • DESC_EVENTO -> descEvento 
  • C_ORGAO_AUTOR -> cOrgaoAutor 
  • TP_AUTOR -> tpAutor 
  • VER_APLIC -> verAplic 

Check the XML file obtained after the name conversion. To download the XML file, follow the steps mentioned in SAP Note 3692197.  

<detEvento versao="1"> 
   <descEvento>Informação de efetivo pagamento integral para liberar crédito presumido do adquirente</descEvento> 
   <cOrgaoAutor>35</cOrgaoAutor> 
   <tpAutor>1</tpAutor> 
   <verAplic>1</verAplic> 
   <indQuitacao>1</indQuitacao> 
</detEvento>

DET_EVENTO Structure Declaration 

Create the structure  ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110. Ensure the structure matches the following definition: 

TYPES: 
  BEGIN OF ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110, 
    a__versao        TYPE string, " XML Attribute 
    desc_evento      TYPE string, 
    c_orgao_autor    TYPE string, 
    tp_autor         TYPE string, 
    ver_aplic        TYPE string, 
    ind_quitacao     TYPE string, 
  END OF ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110.

Populating DET_EVENTO 

You populate the DET_EVENTO  using assignment based on input parameters of the program. Check the following example: 

DATA : ls_event_112110 TYPE ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110. 
ls_event_112110-a__versao = p_ver.         " Version - XML attribute 
ls_event_112110-desc_evento = p_desc.     " Event description 
ls_event_112110-c_orgao_autor = p_orgaut. " Author organization code 
ls_event_112110-tp_autor = p_tpaut.       " Type of authority 
ls_event_112110-ver_aplic = p_verapp.     " Application version 
ls_event_112110-ind_quitacao = p_indqui.  " Settlement indicator

Steps to Send a Generic Event 

Step 1: Declare and Populate IS_GENERIC_EVENT 

The IS_GENERIC_EVENT structure contains high-level control fields required for all types of events, including details such as issuing state, issuer's CNPJ, and access key (P_ACCKEY). Use the following template to populate the structure: 

DATA : ls_generic_event        TYPE nfe_cloud_nfe_map_gnrc_evt. 
ls_generic_event-uuid                = lo_uuid_generator->generate_uuid( ). " Unique identifier 
ls_generic_event-authorize_uuid      = p_authid.                           " Reference UUID 
ls_generic_event-issuing_state       = p_state.                           " State code 
ls_generic_event-environment_type    = 'HOMOLOGATION'.                    " Environment 
ls_generic_event-issuing_type        = 'NORMAL'.                          " Issuing type 
ls_generic_event-issuer_identifier   = p_issuer.                          " Issuer CNPJ 
ls_generic_event-receiver_identifier = '74544297000192'.                " Receiver CNPJ

Step 2: Declare and Populate Specific DET_EVENTO 

Based on the event type (P_TYPE), decide the specific structure for DET_EVENTO. For example: 

If P_TYPE = '112110', use the predefined structure ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110: 

DATA : ls_event_112110 TYPE ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110. 
ls_event_112110-a__versao = p_ver.         " Attributes mapped as XML attributes 
ls_event_112110-desc_evento = p_desc. 
ls_event_112110-c_orgao_autor = p_orgaut. 
ls_event_112110-tp_autor = p_tpaut. 
ls_event_112110-ver_aplic = p_verapp. 
ls_event_112110-ind_quitacao = p_indqui. 
ls_generic_event-event_info-det_evento->* = ls_event_112110.  " Assigning DET_EVENTO structure

Step 3: Send the Event 

Invoke the SEND_GENERIC_EVENT method:

TRY. 
  ls_result = lo_processor->send_generic_event( 
      is_generic_event       = ls_generic_event 
      is_company_definition  = ls_company_defition ). 
CATCH cx_nfe_cloud_invalid_value INTO lx_invalid_value. 
  lx_invalid_value->raise_message( ). 
  RETURN. 
ENDTRY.

Checking Event Status 

To verify the status of sent events, follow these steps: 

  1. Service Locator: Use CREATE_SERVICE_LOCATOR_OBJECT from the CL_J_1BNFE_CF_MONITOR class. 
  1. Service Type Parameter: Reference C_SERVICE_EVENT_STATUS from CL_J_1BNFE_CF_CONSTANT. 
  1. Map Events and Generate JSON: Utilize the STRUCTURE_SERIALIZATION method from CL_J_1BNFE_CF_EVENT_UPDATE. 
  1. Client and OA2C Creation: Use SET_REQUEST_JSON and SEND_REQUEST_TO_CLOUD methods from CL_J_1BNFE_CF_SERVICE_COMM. 
  1. Transform JSON Response: Apply GET_RESPONSE_FROM_CLOUD to convert the response into an NF-e format. 
  1. Develop Response Structure: EVENT_TABLE_DESERIALIZATION method helps integrate this into an NF-e structure. 

Building Your Application 

Beyond these steps, you'll need to develop or extend your applications to: 

  • Fill in necessary event data. 
  • Trigger creation and submission based on business processes. 
  • Implement error handling, logging, and monitoring according to your compliance standards. 

That's a wrap for today! I hope this guide serves as a handy reference for anyone navigating the intricacies of sending events in SAP. Stay tuned for more insights and happy coding! 

Until next time,

Natália

SAP e-Invoicing Application Engineer

entry.title: SAP BTP - APIM - Advanced Domain Routing API-Proxy Pattern for Governing Similar Backend Endpoints
entry.content:
Introduction

This article presents an advanced API Management pattern for SAP landscapes, where a single API Proxy represents one business contract and dynamically routes requests to multiple SAP CPI iFlows belonging to the same business process and domain.

The goal is not to reduce the number of APIs, but to increase governance, observability, and semantic clarity, while keeping analytics consolidated at the business-domain level.

In the previous blog  [ Blog removed as per of my request to SAP Mentors the solution proposed there has become deprecated ] where I explained the way where one API Proxy endpoint can routing the messages for mutiple targets endpoins, in this case Iflows in SAP CPI for one specific package.

I could not present a clear view how to monitoring those messages clearly in the dashboard, so the intention of this blog is present how to create the custom dimension, how to setup the statistic collector policies and the result in the custom dashboard SAP APIM.

However, centralizing traffic often creates a visibility vacuum. This point was raised by @MateuszPiotrowski , I didn't add in previous blog because was too large already.

Important Note (Read First)

Figure 1 - Outside these constraints, this approach becomes an anti-pattern.

The "Invisible Traffic" 

When some business domains over a SAP CPI package, splittled by diferent (iFlows) following the same pattern of endpoint , share a single API Proxy, standard analytics become a "black box." In the default dashboard, all traffic appears under the same Proxy name. 

In this post, we will bridge this gap. I will demonstrate how to implement using JavaScript Policy and the Statistics Collector policy, we will "unmask" the Domain Routing Proxy traffic, providing full transparency directly within the SAP APIM Analytics Dashboard.

The Strategy - Mapping the iflows with Javascript Policy

To solve the "visibility vacuum," we must capture the iFlow’s identity the moment the request hits the Proxy, the sender, the iflow, the package if needed and others details.

API Domain Routing Proxy - ProxyEndpoint routing:

Figure 1 - Routing based on proxy.pathsuffix MatchesPath "/method*"

What means the routing rule ?

So the basic path address of the API Proxy is - https://<apimanagementaddress>/megaproxy/v1 

Any extra call that comes with path /method will generate the routing

The endpoint https://<apimanagementaddress>/megaproxy/v1/method* 

The target Endpoint properties:

In this case different that was presente in the previous blog, I decide to higher the level of cracking, only using the default as a targetEndpoint but in the end is routing for 4 different endpoints

Figure 2 - "Default endpoint" - and properties host and cpi basepath

Routing Mechanism 

The only references that I could find was the SAP but confused to understand -

SAP Enable-Dynamic-Routing

Enable Dynamic Routing Manually

SAP API Management already provides:

  • proxy.pathsuffix
  • custom properties in ProxyEndpoint and TargetEndpoint
  • Conditional flows
  • JavaScript policies
  • Dynamic target resolution

Instead of creating multiple target endpoints, the proxy uses:

  • A single target
  • Dynamic host and path via properties
  • Routing logic based on suffix and context

This is not a hack — it is native SAP API Management functionality that is widely available but rarely explored in depth within the SAP Community. This article formalizes its application as an architectural pattern rather than an implementation trick.

Figure 2 - API Management - API Proxy Design Pattern

Example: Dynamic Routing Logic (Conceptual)

//Routing mechanism
function RoutingCpiEndpoint() {
    
var suffix = context.getVariable("proxy.pathsuffix");
if (suffix == null) {
    suffix = "";
}
var targetBase = context.getVariable("target.cpi.host");
var cpipath = context.getVariable("target.cpi.basepath")

// Use the + operator for compatibility
var finalUrl = targetBase.toString() + cpipath.toString() + suffix.toString();

// Set it back to a context variable so the target can use it
context.setVariable("target.url", finalUrl);

}

Samples of URL's after the groovy:

This line is responsable to extract the cpi.path and cpi.host from the Properties Configured in the Target Endpoint:

Figure 3 - Custom properties in the Target Endpoint

var finalUrl = targetBase.toString() + cpipath.toString() + suffix.toString();

If you analises this somehow procude another security layer, because the APIM contains the whole https path, the consumer only one part.

Urls expose to the consumer:

  • https://<apimaddress>/megaproxy/v1/methoddelete
  • https://<apimaddress>/megaproxy/v1/methodpost
  • https://<apimaddress>/megaproxy/v1/methodput
  • https://<apimaddress>/megaproxy/v1/methodget

Url's generate inside the API PROXY:

  • https://<backendfinal endpoint>/http/cpi/methoddelete
  • https://<backendfinal endpoint>/http/cpi/methodpost
  • https://<backendfinal endpoint>/http/cpi/methodput
  • https://<backendfinal endpoint>/http/cpi/methodget

Test Proposal via postman for methoddelete:

Figure 3 - Postman test of endpoint /methoddelete

Figure 4 - CPI Monitoring - Iflow.Template.MethodDelete

The Real Innovation: Business-Oriented Analytics

Routing is not the innovation, have a clear visibility of which API and Sender Consumer is.

Enriching the api-proxy , SAP APIM Analytics can show:

  • Calls per sender system
  • Calls per CPI iFlow or another backend system api service
  • Success vs error rates per process variant
  • Traffic distribution across the domain

The JavaScript policy enriches SAP API Management analytics by providing clear visibility into endpoint usage, sender system identification, and process execution outcomes (success and failure).

//Set custom headers with name of Iflow
function setCustomHeaders() {

    var path = context.getVariable("proxy.pathsuffix");
    var sourceSystem = context.getVariable("request.header.X-Sender-ID");
    var packageName = "sap.scn.package";
    var iflowName = "UnknownIflow";
    var senderid = sourceSystem ? sourceSystem : "UnknownSender";

    if (path === "/methoddelete") {
        iflowName = "Iflow.Template.MethodDelete";
        context.setVariable("custom.senderid", senderid);
    }
    else if (path === "/methodget") {
        iflowName = "Iflow.Template.MethodGet";
        context.setVariable("custom.senderid", senderid);
    }
    else if (path === "/methodpost") {
        iflowName = "Iflow.Template.MethodPost";
        context.setVariable("custom.senderid", senderid);
    }
    else if (path === "/methodput") {
        iflowName = "Iflow.Template.MethodPut";
        context.setVariable("custom.senderid", senderid);
    }

    context.setVariable("custom.package_name", packageName);
    context.setVariable("custom.iflow_name", iflowName);
}

Custom Metrics Setup:

Recorded data is only useful if it can be visualized. You must prepare the ground in the Analytics portal before the policy can successfully register data:

  • Navigate to Analyze > Settings > Custom Metrics/Dimensions.
  • Add a new dimension named sapcpiIflow.
  • Expert Insight: SAP will prefix these fields as custom_sapcpiIflow and custom_senderid. This is the exact name you will reference in your policy and search for in your reports.

Figure 5 - Create Custom Dimensions that will be used in Policy Statistic Collector

Figure 6 - Create two dimensions, iflowname and senderid.

Policy Statistic Collector:

As you can see in the tag Statistic reffering to custom_sapcpiIflow with the reference of custom.iflow_name created by the javascript above as sample.

  • <Statistic name='custom_sapcpiIflow' ref='custom.iflow_name' type='string'>0</Statistic>
  • <Statistic name='custom_senderid' ref='custom.senderid' type='string'>0</Statistic>
<!--Specify Stats collector policy to add custom dimensions and measures -->
 <StatisticsCollector async='false' continueOnError='false' enabled='true' xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
 <Statistics>

<!-- prepopulated template -->
<!-- Uncomment Statistic which needs to be collected and define reference variable-->
<Statistic name='custom_sapcpiIflow' ref='custom.iflow_name' type='string'>0</Statistic>
<Statistic name='custom_senderid' ref='custom.senderid' type='string'>0</Statistic>

</Statistics>
</StatisticsCollector>

Add in seguency:

Figure 7 - Those policies should be added in the last step into the Target Endpoint Pre-Flow

The Result as SAP CPI as backend:

Figure 8 - APIM - Business-Oriented Analytics Dashboard

Once this configuration is live, you move from a generic chart to a Business Iflow Dashboard. You can now generate

  • Volume Tracking: Exactly how many calls are being processed by iFlow A vs. iFlow B or C?
  • Targeted Performance: Which specific iFlow endpoint is experiencing high latency?
  • Error Granularity: Which iFlow is generating the most errors? Instead of seeing "Proxy Errors," you can pinpoint which specific backend integration is failing

Image - 8 - Custom Dashboard monitoring SAP APIM

Sender system identifier:

Image 9 - Indentifier of Sender System

Image 10 - Indentifier of Sender System - Coke - and which Iflow endpoint

Image 11 - CPI Iflows

11 - When This Pattern Is Allowed

Conclusion:

The Dynamic Routing Proxy moves beyond URL-based routing and acts as a centralized API layer.

The single API Proxy endpoint, teams gain consolidated visibility into CPI iFlow API's, traffic patterns, and error behavior, all through one unified SAP API Management dashboard.

Kind regards,

Viana

entry.title: Introducing SAP Business Data Cloud test, demo and development service
entry.content:
If you’re an SAP Partner thinking about where data, applications, and AI truly come together, this session is for you.

We’re hosting a webinar on Introducing SAP Business Data Cloud test, demo and development service, and it’s designed to give partners a clear, practical view of what’s coming—and how to get hands-on quickly.

We’ll walk through how SAP Business Data Cloud fits into SAP’s overall product strategy, then get very concrete: how to order the new test, demo, and development service via SAP for Me and SAP Store, what’s included in the initial release (available from November 2025), and what’s planned for early 2026.

The thing is capacity-based pricing can feel abstract.  So, we’ll break it down, honestly, with guidance on estimating capacity units for real partner scenarios.

Plus, we’ll explore how partners can build analytical and AI-enriched apps on SAP Business Data Cloud and even commercialize them via SAP Store.  We’ll also cover alternative options like the 30-day free trial and SAP Demo Environment 2.0.

Plenty of time for Q&A. Clear next steps.  No fluff.

👉 Register now https://partneredge.sap.com/en/library/education/psd/2025/oct/e_oe_te_w_PSD_WEB_00012047.html

#SAP #SAPBTP #SAPPartners #SAPBusinessDataCloud #SAPEcosystem #DataAndAI

entry.title: Setting Up PostgreSQL for SAP BTP Development: A Practical Guide
entry.content:
Setting Up PostgreSQL for SAP BTP Development: A Practical Guide

Part 1 of a series — next up: implementing OAuth with XSUAA and PostgreSQL

Not every BTP application needs HANA Cloud. PostgreSQL on SAP BTP is a managed database service running on hyperscaler infrastructure. Credentials arrive via VCAP_SERVICES in Cloud Foundry or Kubernetes secrets in Kyma.

When Should You Choose PostgreSQL Over HANA Cloud?

Need analytics or calculation views? → HANA Cloud
Need MTX support? → HANA Cloud


Everything else? → PostgreSQL

That's really it. If you're not using HANA-specific features, you're paying premium prices for a standard relational database. PostgreSQL handles CRUD just as well at a fraction of the cost.

Provisioning PostgreSQL on SAP BTP

Prerequisites: Setting Up Entitlements

Before you can create a PostgreSQL instance, your subaccount needs the right entitlements. For trial account it's set up by default.

Method 1: Creating via BTP Cockpit (UI)

This approach works well when you're getting started or creating a one-off instance.

Step 1: Navigate to your Cloud Foundry Space

  • BTP Cockpit → Subaccount → Cloud Foundry → Spaces → [Your Space]

Step 2: Open the Service Marketplace

  • Click Services in the left menu → Service Marketplace

Step 3: Find PostgreSQL

  • Search for "PostgreSQL" or look for "PostgreSQL, hyperscaler option"
  • Click on the tile

Step 4: Create a new instance

  • Click the Create button

Step 5: Name your instance psql-dev and click Create

The provisioning takes 5-15 minutes.

Method 2: Creating via CF CLI

cf login -a https://api.cf.eu10.hana.ondemand.com
cf target -o my-organization -s my-space

# Create the service instance
cf create-service postgresql-db free psql-dev

# Monitor the creation progress
cf service psql-dev

The cf service command will show status like "create in progress" initially, then "create succeeded" when ready.

Getting Your Database Credentials

Once your instance is created, you need credentials to connect. There are two approaches depending on your use case.

For Applications: Service Binding

If you're deploying an application to Cloud Foundry, the standard approach is binding:

# Bind the service to your app
cf bind-service my-application psql-dev

# Restage to pick up the new binding
cf restage my-application

After binding, your application receives credentials via the VCAP_SERVICES environment variable. Here's what that looks like (simplified):

{
  "postgresql-db": [{
    "credentials": {
      "hostname": "postgres-abc123.database.sap.hana.ondemand.com",
      "port": "5432",
      "dbname": "postgres",
      "username": "user_xyz",
      "password": "generated-secure-password",
      "uri": "postgres://user_xyz:password@hostname:5432/postgres?sslmode=verify-full",
      "sslcert": "-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----\n...",
      "sslrootcert": "-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----\n..."
    }
  }]
}

Important: Notice the SSL certificates. BTP PostgreSQL requires SSL connections — this isn't optional.

For Local Development

BTP PostgreSQL isn't publicly accessible from your laptop. For local development, just run PostgreSQL locally via Docker — it's faster anyway.

Option 1: Local PostgreSQL via Docker

For CAP apps, use the pg.yaml shown in the CAP section below with cds watch --profile pg. For non-CAP apps, the same Docker setup works — just connect to localhost:5432 with user/password postgres.

Option 2: Deploy pgAdmin on BTP

Need to browse your BTP database with a GUI? Deploy pgAdmin directly on Cloud Foundry — it runs inside the network and connects without tunneling.

manifest.yml:

applications:
- name: pgadmin-web
  memory: 1G
  disk_quota: 1G
  health-check-type: process
  docker:
    image: dpage/pgadmin4:latest
  random-route: true
  env:
    PGADMIN_DEFAULT_EMAIL: admin@admin.com
    PGADMIN_DEFAULT_PASSWORD: admin123
cf push

Open the route URL from the output, login with the credentials above, and add your server using the hostname/port/username/password from your service key.

Connecting from Different Application Types

Now for the practical part — actually connecting your code to the database. I'll cover the major scenarios.

Scenario 1: CAP Application (Node.js)

The @cap-js/postgres package provides official PostgreSQL support.

Setup:

cds add postgres

Local development with Docker:

# pg.yaml
services:
  db:
    image: postgres:alpine
    environment: { POSTGRES_PASSWORD: postgres }
    ports: ['5432:5432']
docker compose -f pg.yaml up -d
cds watch --profile pg

The @cap-js/postgres package comes with default credentials under profile [pg] that match the Docker defaults — no configuration needed.

Scenario 2: Plain Node.js Application (Express, Fastify, etc.)

Here's where things get interesting for non-CAP developers. You can use PostgreSQL with any Node.js framework using the standard pg package.

Installation:

npm install pg @sap/xsenv

Connection setup:

// db.js - Database connection module
const { Pool } = require('pg');
const xsenv = require('@sap/xsenv');

// Load environment (works both locally with default-env.json and on CF)
xsenv.loadEnv();

// Get PostgreSQL credentials from VCAP_SERVICES
const pgCredentials = xsenv.getServices({ 
  postgres: { label: 'postgresql-db' } 
}).postgres;

// Create connection pool with SSL configuration
const pool = new Pool({
  host: pgCredentials.hostname,
  port: parseInt(pgCredentials.port, 10),
  database: pgCredentials.dbname,
  user: pgCredentials.username,
  password: pgCredentials.password,
});

// Test the connection on startup
pool.query('SELECT NOW()')
  .then(() => console.log('✅ PostgreSQL connected'))
  .catch(err => console.error('❌ PostgreSQL connection failed:', err));

module.exports = pool;

Using it in your routes:

// routes/users.js
const express = require('express');
const pool = require('../db');
const router = express.Router();

router.get('/users', async (req, res) => {
  try {
    const result = await pool.query('SELECT id, name, email FROM users');
    res.json(result.rows);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error('Query error:', err);
    res.status(500).json({ error: 'Database error' });
  }
});

router.post('/users', async (req, res) => {
  const { name, email } = req.body;
  try {
    const result = await pool.query(
      'INSERT INTO users (name, email) VALUES ($1, $2) RETURNING *',
      [name, email]
    );
    res.status(201).json(result.rows[0]);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error('Insert error:', err);
    res.status(500).json({ error: 'Database error' });
  }
});

module.exports = router;

What's Next: Building OAuth Authentication with XSUAA

Now that you have PostgreSQL running on BTP, we're ready to build something practical.

In the next article, we'll implement OAuth 2.0 authentication using XSUAA and PostgreSQL — without relying on the CAP framework.

See you in Part 2!

Resources

  • CAP: Using PostgreSQL
  • PostgreSQL on SAP BTP - Hyperscaler Option
  • @cap-js/postgres package

entry.title: From Meter Read to Bill: Where Utilities Lose Time—and How SAP BTP Fixes It
entry.content:
For utility executives, the Meter-to-Cash (M2C) cycle is more than a back-office function; it is the fundamental engine of liquidity and the primary touchpoint for customer trust. Yet, even in the era of advanced infrastructure, many organizations remain tethered to reactive, batch-driven processes that bleed operational margin through "hidden" inefficiencies.

While SAP S/4HANA Utilities (IS-U) provides a robust transactional core, the modern energy landscape—defined by decentralized assets and hyper-connected prosumers—demands a higher tier of agility. This is where SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) serves as the critical orchestration layer, transforming the M2C cycle from a series of manual handoffs into an intelligent, automated value stream.

I. The "Accepted Inefficiencies" of Legacy M2C

Despite the widespread deployment of Advanced Metering Infrastructure (AMI), many utilities still operate under a "Batch & Fix" paradigm. Process friction is often accepted as the cost of doing business, manifesting in three critical areas:

 

  • Data Latency & Quality Decay: In hybrid meter environments, missing or stale reads trigger estimated billing. This doesn't just delay revenue; it initiates a cycle of high-volume disputes and costly rework.
  • The "Human Middleware" Bottleneck: Exceptions—such as high-usage flags or zero-consumption events—frequently default to manual queues. Relying on "tribal knowledge" and spreadsheets for resolution creates a non-scalable operational model.
  • Disconnected Operational Silos: Metering, billing, and field services often operate in data vacuums. When a field repair is completed, the delay in notifying the billing engine results in missed revenue cycles and customer frustration.

 

II. SAP BTP: The Intelligence Layer for Revenue Resilience

Modernization does not require a "rip-and-replace" of your core ERP. Instead, SAP BTP adopts a side-by-side extensibility model, allowing utilities to augment their core IS-U logic with cloud-native intelligence.

1. Event-Driven Orchestration (The End of Batch Processing)

Leveraging SAP Integration Suite and Advanced Event Mesh, utilities can transition to real-time operations. Instead of waiting for midnight batch runs to identify failures, the system reacts to granular events. A persistent communication failure in a smart meter can instantly trigger a field service order, ensuring the next billing cycle remains based on actual data rather than estimates.

2. Hyper-Automation via Intelligent Workflows

With SAP Build Process Automation, utilities can digitize the "gray areas" of M2C. By applying AI-driven business rules to exception handling, low-risk anomalies (e.g., seasonal zero-consumption in known vacation properties) can be auto-resolved. Analysts are then free to focus exclusively on complex cases, shifting the workforce from data entry to high-value exception management.

3. Predictive Insights & Proactive CX

Using SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere, leaders gain a "Control Tower" view of the entire M2C pipeline. Predictive models can identify accounts at risk of "Bill Shock" before the invoice is even sent, allowing for proactive customer outreach—significantly reducing call center volumes and improving Net Promoter Scores (NPS).

III. Case Study: Reducing Exception Latency by 90%

A leading regional utility faced chronic delays in resolving billing exceptions, with an average resolution time of 72 hours. This backlog directly impacted cash flow and increased customer complaints.

By deploying an automated workflow on SAP BTP, the utility integrated its meter data validation logic with historical usage patterns.

 

  • Solution: The system performed automated "sanity checks" on 60% of flagged exceptions.
  • Outcome: Average resolution time dropped from 3 days to 4 hours.
  • Business Impact: A 40% reduction in analyst workload and a 25% decrease in regulatory escalations.

 

IV. The Strategic Imperative: Small Gains, Large Scale

In a high-volume utility environment, micro-efficiencies deliver macro-impact.

 

  • Financial Liquidity: Reducing Days Sales Outstanding (DSO) by even 2 days through faster billing release can unlock millions in working capital.
  • Regulatory Compliance: Automated, auditable workflows ensure that every billing decision is documented and compliant with evolving PUC mandates.
  • Future Agility: A "Clean Core" strategy using BTP ensures that as your utility adds EV charging, solar buy-back, or dynamic pricing, your system can adapt without costly re-coding.

 

Conclusion: Digital Transition vs. Transformation

True modernization is not a destination; it is the continuous optimization of your most critical flows. By leveraging SAP BTP to "fix the flow" of the meter-to-cash process, utilities can achieve a rare trifecta: operational cost reduction, revenue acceleration, and a superior customer experience.

The goal is no longer just to generate a bill; it is to deliver Clarity, Predictability, and Trust.

entry.title: What's New in SAP BTP - Q4 2025 Innobytes
entry.content:
Happy new year and welcome back to the SAP BTP Innobytes! 2026 is going to be an exciting year and we have big ideas and a strong strategy for the year ahead! In the meantime, let’s see how we finished out last year with some innovative highlights.

Check out the video below and explore the latest features in Application Development, Integration and more. Enjoy watching!

 

 

Data & Analytics

My Metrics

To keep up with the important numbers and data, let me introduce you to your personalized watchlist to keep up with what really matters: My Metrics in SAP Analytics Cloud on SAP BTP.

You can find it via the My Metrics Card on the new Homepage, bringing together performance cards from stories and models into one easy-to-access space with these core areas:

  • Your Metrics to manage cards
  • Detailed Visualization with instant charts and active filters
  • Smart Insights surfacing automated observations

You can create lists from My Metrics page or directly from a story chart: select a data point that you want to track and add it to an existing list or create a new one. You can name the metric and customize suggested comparisons and default visualizations. It’s now possible to rename, delete, copy or move metrics between different lists. You can Share multiple metrics with tailored permissions and distribute it with different SAC users or teams. 

See these steps in action (starting at 0:09).

Learn more

  • MyMetrics Blog Post

 

App Dev Highlights

Analytical Table with RAP and SAP Fiori

Real-time data analysis tools are essential for decision-making, that’s why SAP BTP ABAB introduced these powerful features for business users.

By adding the annotation @odata.applySupportedForAggregation: #FULL to your data model, you can now unlock advanced aggregation, grouping, and subtotalling directly in Fiori analytical tables. View real-time summarized business data, group by key fields, and dynamically sort and analyse profitability. This way you can simplify analytics for end users, enabling faster, data-driven decisions.

Watch the demo starting at 1:37 to get more insights.

Learn more

  • Developing Read-Only RAP Analytical Tables

 

SAP Build Extensibility Wizard now available in SAP SuccessFactors

You might already know the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard, supporting developers in process creation and UI extensions directly from Cloud ERP apps. This feature is now also available in SAP SuccessFactors.

In this example we want to simplify the process of requesting personal data from new hires in the onboarding process:

  1. Launch the process variant manager from the SAP SuccessFactors application and select the specific HR process you want to extend.
  2. To let the new hire know, that their data has been accepted, we want to add a step of approval. The wizard will walk you through the familiar steps to set up our extension.
  3. You can jump directly into SAP Build to customize this process.
  4. View the process from the SAP SuccessFactors application, reviewing the new hires and the personal data they have collected.
  5. HR will get a notification in the Task Center Inbox and can select approve, notifying the new hire.

The Extensibility wizard can now practice its magic in SAP SuccessFactors, delivering a better experience for our employees with SAP Build.

To watch this innovation example, start the video at 2:41.

Learn more

  • Extensibility Support
  • Understanding Extensibility
  • Extension types

 

Joule Studio Agent Builder

When it comes to making decisions for your business, transparency and control are essential. AI agents can help speed up the process but building AI agents that are both powerful and enterprise-ready is a challenge. How do you combine development speed with the governance and trust your business demands? 

Describe your business goals to your AI conversational Partner and let Joule build an agent that fits your needs. It automatically discovers tools and connects to external systems through the framework support for MCP. Giving the agent deep business context enables smarter decision-making. The timeline feature gives you full transparency, showing every step of the agent's logic, essential for debugging and governance. 

Start the demo at 4:21 to learn all about the Agent Builder in Joule Studio.

Learn more

  • Joule Studio Learning Series (Blog Post)
  • SAP Learning: Building your first Joule Skill
  • Joule Studio

 

Integration

Local OData API access & SAP HANA support in Edge Integration Cell

When it comes to manage persistence and monitoring in hybrid landscapes, integration is an essential step to make it more flexible.

Edge Integration Cell now supports SAP HANA as both a database and datastore, offering an alternative to PostgreSQL and Redis. If your landscape already runs on HANA, avoid maintaining separate persistence systems by unifying your data layer. One SAP HANA instance can be used for multiple Edge to keep everything consistent and centralized. To ensure the reliability of your integrations even if the cloud connection isn’t available, try the Local OData API access for your Edge runtime. You can retrieve message processing logs, data stores, and other runtime info through local GET APIs.

To use the Local API Access,

  • Activate the API Plan support to the cluster using the ELMO UI
  • Modify the configuration by adding a valid API Virtual Host and an API Virtual Host Key Alias

These settings are also available upon onboarding a new Edge node, allowing a stronger performance and visibility into your integrations. 

Watch this part (starting at 5:36) to get more insights.

Learn more

  • SAP Integration Suite
  • Local OData API Access in Edge Integration Cell Runtimes

 

Security

SAP Key Management Service

SAP Key Management Service (KMS) enables customers to manage encryption keys to business compliance and regulations. Group systems and keys in key configurations according to your requirements.   

The Primary Key is the active one for encryption. The SAP KMS supports Hold Your Own Key (HYOK) and Bring Your Own Key (BYOK) by importing Your Key. Revoke a key at any time by disabling or deleting it, leading to a shutdown of the connected systems, locking the data. When assigned to a KMS tenant, connect the system seamless via the UI. The four-eye-principle secures tasks like connecting a system or a key action.

To see this demo in action, watch the video (starting at 7:04).

 

Share your thoughts 

These videos are for YOU, and we would love to hear your impressions. How do you like the video? How can we improve the upcoming videos? Please share your feedback by liking this post or leaving a comment below.

Thank you for your support and happy viewing, sharing, and enjoying!

You Might Also Be Interested In

  • SAP BTP Garage: monthly LIVE webinar with hands-on use case walkthroughs and demos.
  • Unlocking SAP BTP: monthly podcast covering all things SAP BTP.

entry.title: Configure Role Owner Stage Auto Approval in SAP IAG
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog explains how to configure Role Owner Stage Auto Approval in IAG. focusing on setting up the required data objects, business rules, and workflow configuration to automate approvals.

Step 1: Create Data Object

Create a data object called RoleOwnerAttributes. This object holds the input values used to determine whether the Role Owner stage should be automatically approved.

Add the following attributes to the data object:

  • roleName (String)
  • roleCriticality (String)
  • roleApprover (String)
  • roleBusinessProcess (String)
  • roleSubprocess (String)
  • roleRiskCount (Number)








 

 

 

Step 2: Create another Data Object 

Create another data object called AutoApproveRoleOwnerStage. This object stores the output of the rule.

Add the following attributes to the data object:

  • roleName (String)
  • roleOwnerAutoStage (Boolean)

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Step 3: Create Local Rule

Create a local rule called RoleOwnerStageAutoRule

decision table settings:

  • Use the fields from RoleOwnerAttributes (Step 1) as the conditions.
  • Use AutoApproveRoleOwnerStage (Step 2) as the result.

Result Attributes:

  • Role Owner Auto Stage → Access: Editable
  • Role Name → Access: Hidden
  • Set the hardcoded value as the roleName from RoleOwnerAttributes.


 

 

 

 

 

 

 


In this scenario, the condition is defined based on the Role Name.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Step 4: Create Rule Set

 

Create a rule set called RoleOwnerRuleSet  and add the local rule RoleOwnerStageAutoRule (from Step 3) to it.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 
Step 5: Create Rule Service

Create a rule service called AutoApproveRoleOwnerStage.

  • Import → RoleOwnerAttributes (from Step 1)

  • Result → AutoApproveRoleOwnerStage (from Step 2)

 

 

 

 

 
 
 
 
Step 6: Assign Rule Service

Assign the rule service AutoApproveRoleOwnerStage (from Step 5) to the rule set RoleOwnerRuleSet (from Step 4).

 

 

 

 

 
 
 
Step 7: Activate and Deploy

Activate all the created objects and deploy the business rule service. If any changes are made, the service must be deployed again.

Existing Workflow Setup

In the current existing workflow, the access request is configured to follow the Role Owner approval path as the stage 1 during the approval process.

 

 

 

 

 
 
 
Testing Scenario

The following test scenario was performed to validate the configuration:

  • An access request was raised for the role PR_approver_0_1M.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

  • The audit log shows that the request was automatically approved by the system.

  • The Access request status shows that it moved to the Risk Owner stage, confirming that the Role Owner stage was automatically approved successfully.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 
Conclusion

Role Owner stage auto approval reduces manual effort and speeds up the approval process for eligible access requests. Using rule-based conditions, organizations can automatically approve condition based requests while keeping manual approvals for critical cases.

entry.title: Connecting IAS with Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) (Part 3)
entry.content:
In Part 1, the role of SAP Cloud Identity Services – Identity Authentication (IAS) as the central identity layer for Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) was introduced.
In Part 2, an IAS tenant was created and made accessible on SAP BTP.

This article completes the setup by connecting the IAS tenant to DIV, explaining how authentication and authorization are enforced, and showing how administrators and end users are granted access to DIV provisioning and wallet tenants.

 

Authentication and Authorization Overview

Once IAS is connected to DIV, all access to DIV components is mediated by IAS. This applies to both:

  • DIV Provisioning UI (administrative access)
  • DIV Wallet Tenants (end-user access)

During authentication, IAS performs two checks:

  1. Authentication by verifying the user’s identity via the federated corporate identity provider
  2. Authorization by validating whether the authenticated user is allowed to access the requested DIV tenant or application

Only if both checks succeed access is granted.

This model ensures that authentication and authorization decisions are consistently enforced across the DIV components.

 

Step 1: Starting DIV Provisioning via SAP for Me

The connection between DIV and IAS is established during the DIV provisioning process in SAP for Me.

In SAP for Me, navigate to Systems & Provisioning → Provisioning

The Provisioning tab lists all systems that can be provisioned for the account. In the section “Systems to be Provisioned”, a Start Provisioning button is available (Figure 1).

Selecting this option initiates the provisioning workflow for DIV.

Figure 1: SAP for Me - Systems & Provisioning - Provisioning

 

During the provisioning process for DIV, an IAS tenant must be selected. The provisioning screen displays the available SAP Cloud Identity Services tenants. This might be the URL created during the previous blog article.

Typically, the default IAS tenant associated with the BTP global account is selected (Figure 2). Once confirmed, the provisioning request can be submitted. After a short processing time, the provisioning status changes from requested to provided. The DIV Provisioning Service becomes available and is automatically linked to the selected IAS tenant.

Figure 2: SAP for Me - Start New Provisioning Request

 

Step 2: IAS Application Created for DIV

As part of the provisioning process, an IAS application representing the DIV service is automatically created and linked to the corresponding BTP subaccount. This application functions as the technical anchor point for all authentication and authorization decisions related to DIV.

In the IAS Admin Console, this application appears under Applications & Resources, grouped under the relevant BTP subaccount (Figure 3).

Figure 3: DIV application automatically created in the IAS Admin Console and linked to the corresponding SAP BTP subaccount.

 

Step 3: Restricting Application Access in IAS

By default, IAS applications can be configured with different access modes. For enterprise DIV deployments, access must be restricted.

In the IAS Admin Console:

  1. Open the DIV application (Figure 4)
  2. Navigate to the Authentication and Access tab
  3. Select Private access mode

The Private option ensures that:

  • Users cannot self-register
  • Only users explicitly imported or provisioned are allowed to authenticate

This setting is mandatory for controlled, enterprise-grade DIV deployments.

Figure 4: Configuration of application access mode for the DIV application in IAS

 

Step 4: Authorization Model for DIV

IAS enforces authorization separately for:

  • DIV Provisioning UI
  • DIV Wallet Tenants

This separation enables fine-grained access control and clear separation of duties.

 

DIV Provisioning Authorization

The following user groups are created in the IAS tenant by default:

  • DIV_Provisioning_Admin

  • DIV_Provisioning_Viewer

Only users assigned to these groups are able to access provisioning functions such as tenant creation, configuration, and user management.

 

DIV Wallet Authorization

For wallet access, IAS restricts users to specific wallet tenants. Even if authentication succeeds, access is denied if the user is not authorized for the requested tenant.

This prevents lateral access between departments or partner organizations in multi-tenant environments.

 

Step 5: Importing Users and Assigning Roles in IAS

Users must be explicitly imported into IAS and assigned to the appropriate DIV-related groups.

In the IAS Admin Console:

  1. Navigate to Users & Authorizations
  2. Select the DIV application
  3. Choose Import Users and upload a CSV file (Figure 5)

The CSV file contains user attributes such as:

  • Login name
  • Email address
  • Status
  • Group memberships

An example CSV file includes a groups column containing DIV-specific roles (Figure 6). These group assignments determine whether a user receives provisioning access, wallet access, or both.

Figure 5: User and authorization management for the DIV application in the IAS Admin Console, including user import via CSV

 

Figure 6: Example CSV file used to import users into IAS with assigned DIV-specific authorization groups

 

Step 6: Authentication and Access Enforcement

When a user attempts to access a DIV component, IAS performs an authorization check.

For example, when accessing the DIV Provisioning UI, the user is first redirected to IAS. The authentication screen displays the associated BTP subaccount and requests credentials (Figure 7).

Figure 7: IAS authentication and authorization check triggered when accessing the DIV Provisioning UI

 

Only if:

  • Authentication via the corporate identity provider succeeds, and
  • The user belongs to a group authorized for the requested application,

is access granted and the user redirected back to DIV.

 

Resulting Architecture and Security Model

After completing the steps described above, the following architecture and security characteristics are in place:

  • IAS acts as the single authentication entry point for all DIV components
  • Corporate identity providers remain the source of user identities
  • Authorization is centrally enforced through IAS groups and role assignments
  • Administrative and end-user access paths are clearly separated at the application level
  • Multi-tenant isolation is consistently enforced

The trust relationship between the SAP BTP subaccount and IAS is established during provisioning and configuration. At runtime, IAS issues authentication tokens containing group claims. These tokens are validated directly by the DIV applications based on the preconfigured trust.

The result is a secure, scalable, and enterprise-ready DIV setup aligned with real-world organizational structures (Figure 8).

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Figure 8: High-level authentication and authorization flow for DIV using IAS

 

💡This concludes the three-part series on integrating SAP Cloud Identity Services – Identity Authentication with Decentralized Identity Verification.

 

Read more

⬅️   Go back to Creating and Accessing an IAS Tenant on SAP BTP (Part 2)

⬅️⬅️   Go back to Why IAS Is Essential for Enterprise DIV Implementations (Part 1)

 

  • Introduction to SAP Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) and Related SSI Blog Posts 
  • Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI): A Usage Catalyst for Data Spaces 
  • Feature Scope Description for Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV help page)
  • What Are Cloud Identity Services? (IAS help page)
  • Import or Update Users for a Specific Application (IAS help page)

entry.title: Connecting SAP S/4HANA On-Prem Directly to Advanced Event Mesh using Cloud Connector - finally!
entry.content:
With Package Integration 1.4.0 (December 2025), the Advanced Event Mesh Adapter for SAP Integration Suite delivers several noteworthy updates.

One of these has been requested repeatedly by customers, partners, and SAP architects working in hybrid landscapes:
official support for on-premise connectivity via the SAP Cloud Connector.

In addition to this key enhancement, the release also includes other technical changes, such as an update to the default acknowledgment mode.

What’s New in Package Integration 1.4.0?

1️⃣On-Premise Connectivity via SAP Cloud Connector

The AEM Adapter can now officially route traffic to on-premise systems through the SAP Cloud Connector.

This enables a supported hybrid architecture where:

S/4HANA on-prem produces events
SAP AEM distributes them
Network security remains intact

Important note from the official release notes:

Avoid mixing proxy configurations within the same tenant to prevent unexpected routing behavior.

This is especially critical in complex hybrid tenants.

2️⃣Change of Default Acknowledgment Mode

The default acknowledgment mode has changed from:
      Automatic Immediate
to  Automatic On Exchange Complete

Technical implications:

  • Clearer delivery semantics

  • improved error handling
  • Better alignment with enterprise-grade integration scenarios

Package Integration 1.4.0 introduces multiple technical improvements.
The Cloud Connector support for the Advanced Event Mesh Adapter is a long-requested and architecturally significant enhancement.

It enables a clean, supported reference architecture to connect SAP S/4HANA on-premise directly to SAP Advanced Event Mesh, using SAP Cloud Connector as the secure hybrid backbone.

For SAP architects, this removes a major blocker when designing modern, event-driven hybrid landscapes.

https://api.sap.com/package/AdvancedEventMeshAdapterforSAPIntegrationSuite/documents

entry.title: SAP BTP - IS - ( IA | CPI ) - Extinguishing the EDI-T-REX: A Commander Blueprint for B2B Governance
entry.content:
Spoiler

Disclaimer: This article is written for architects, B2B leads, and senior consultants dealing with large-scale EDI modernization. It focuses on governance, not quick wins.

Please note: This is not a "click-by-click" tutorial or a step-by-step technical manual. Instead, it is a strategic orientation on the mindset and professional positioning required of an SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant (IA + CPI).

My goal is to provide a strategic guide on how to approach a scalable solution and lead a business transformation, rather than just explaining how to configure isolated components without considering the entire ecosystem.

Introduction

In my previous article, SAP BTP - IS - How to become a SAP Integration Suite Consultant - Part IV - I outlined a path for integration professionals to evolve beyond the “CPI Developer” label toward true SAP BTP Integration Suite specialization.

Today, I want to put this into practice by discussing a critical scenario: the modernization of B2B/EDI processes in S/4HANA projects.

Many companies adopting Rise with SAP and Clean Core methodologies still make the strategic mistake of maintaining legacy platforms (such as Seeburger or OpenText) or, even worse, they attempt to rebuild decades of EDI logic within massive and manual CPI iFlows. The result is what I call the "EDI-T-REX Legacy": a heavy, undocumented architecture that no one dares to touch.

SAP BTP Integration Advisor (IA) is the tool that breaks this cycle, transforming what would be a "Frankenstein" of code into clean governance, where the functional team regains control over what is being mapped.

My journey with Integration Advisor has been one of deep technical discovery. Until recently, it was an area I had not explored in depth — which makes the insights shared here the result of focused study and hands-on experimentation rather than inherited project patterns.

Beyond the official course, 'Manage B2B Scenarios Effectively with SAP Integration Suite,' deep-dive material is scarce. I see this tool as the missing piece to provide confidence to business teams and front-line EDI staff. If a greenfield implementation or training were necessary to empower key users, I feel ready for that mission.

I have yet to see Integration Advisor fully adopted in real-world projects at scale. What follows is not a market benchmark, but a technically grounded action plan derived from deep study and architectural reasoning.

A Guide, Not a Critique

Once again, this blog serves as an instructional guide and a compilation of the best resources I found on my journey. My intent is not to criticize existing content—there is plenty of great material out there. However, much of it follows a 'click here, click there' approach without sufficient architectural context, or it is split across multiple blogs where the narrative becomes disconnected

Quick Project Setup B2B EDI

Let me show you an imaginary project conversation.

The following imaginary conversation highlights a common mistake: treating SAP BTP Integration Advisor as an afterthought rather than the core of your EDI governance and structural framework.

 

Enterprise Architect / Solution Architect

Our next big challenge is a global B2B EDI migration involving ~50 international partners across multiple legacy platforms.

We are dealing with a chaotic mix of standards: EDIFACT, ANSI X12, VDA, and RosettaNet each with its own partner-specific deviations.

But let’s be honest: Are we actually migrating platforms, or just moving decades of undocumented business semantics into a new home?

Are we ready to finally implement a true semantic layer, or is the plan to simply replicate 'partner-to-partner spaghetti' inside a modern tool? We must face the reality:

EDIFACT is not just EDIFACT, and X12 is not just X12—every partner speaks a different dialect.

Who actually owns these standards and the partner lifecycle today or are we just hostage to tribal knowledge?

SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant - Commander 

Before we discuss tools, we must align on one non-negotiable principle: We are not migrating EDI flows; we are rebuilding semantic governance.

Utilizing the MIG (Message Implementation Guideline) objects in SAP Integration Advisor, we will centralize business semantics, not just technical mappings.

MAGs are mandatory—they are the bridge that replaces tribal knowledge with explicit, automated rules.

The TPM (Trading Partner Management), ownership shifts from 'people' to the 'platform.' Every contract, structure, and version becomes a managed asset, ensuring seamless onboarding for future partners.

Let’s be clear: Integration Advisor won’t magically fix our B2B mess; it will expose every weakness we have. Our job is to build the structure that finally fixes them.

Enterprise Architect / Solution Architect

We’re talking a lot about governance, but at runtime, reality hits hard. How do you prevent this from becoming an 'adapter hell' HTTPS, AS2, SFTP, and even legacy OFTP2 or X.400?

From a Cloud Integration (CPI) design perspective, we still face a massive 'zoo' of custom flows.

How do you handle Interchange Control Number (ICN) collisions when multiple partners hit the same number range?

What about the Ingress logic: are we just going to let developers hide 'quick fixes' in Groovy scripts to handle encoding issues or non-standard delimiters?

Also, where is the boundary for API Management? Are we exposing EDIFACT/X12 via REST wrappers, or are we sticking to the traditional batch mindset?

If we move to BTP, how do we handle Functional Acknowledgments (997/CONTRL) without doubling the message volume in our monitoring tools? Today, support teams are already drowning in dashboards—adding APIM and TPM feels like adding two more layers of complexity.

How do we achieve a Single Pane of Glass for monitoring a payload that travels from an AS2 adapter, through the EDI Splitter, into a MAG transformation, and finally to an IDoc in S/4HANA?

SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant - Commander 

To avoid 'adapter hell,' we move away from custom iFlows  SAP already provides the blueprint for these challenges through standard, battle-tested packages: the EDI Integration Templates for standalone scenarios and the Trading Partner Management (TPM) V2 for full-scale governance.

We can also place SAP APIM in front for HTTPS and SOAP to handle quota management and spike arrest. This prevents overflowing SAP CPI and the backend system by effectively controlling message volume.

Decouple communication protocols from business logic using JMS.

aIn the BTP runtime, ICN (Interchange Control Number) collisions are prevented because the system manages number ranges per partner context, ensuring unique sequences regardless of the format.

Instead of hiding 'quick fixes' in Groovy scripts, we use the Integration Advisor (IA) to handle delimiters and encoding through formalized metadata, keeping the design clean and visible. For acknowledgments like 997 or CONTRL, we use status correlation to link them directly to the original message; this updates the transaction state instead of creating a second 'ghost' message that clutters the dashboard.

Finally, we achieve that 'Single Pane of Glass' by using Application Correlation IDs that track the payload from the Sender ingress, through the MAG transformation, all the way to the IDoc in S/4HANA or ODATA, making the entire journey searchable in one view.

Regarding legacy or niche protocols like X.400, OFTP2, AS1, or AS3, while they may require third-party adapters, my strategic approach is to first maximize the native capabilities of the Integration Suite to keep costs lean and the architecture 'Clean Core.'

As for the 'complexity' of the platform: consider it handled.

I will personally lead an internal enablement program to train our front-line EDI operations team. From mastering MIGs and MAGs to navigating the TPM dashboard.

I will ensure everyone is empowered to manage these flows with confidence. You focus on the business strategy, I will ensure the integration engine and the team are ready for the mission.

Enterprise Architect / Solution Architect

Fair enough. That is exactly the level of technical clarity and leadership I was looking for to validate the viability of this project. You’ve addressed the architectural risks and, more importantly, the human element of this migration.

We have a green light. Let’s execute a phased approach: we will start with two strategic vendors and two EDI formats to establish our 'Golden Template.'

This will allow the team to build confidence in the SAP Integration Advisor (MIG, MAG, and TPM) ecosystem without overwhelming the operation.

As our Commander, I’m tasking you to begin the preparation of the platform and the enablement material. I want our front-line team fully aligned with your vision.

I’m confident that under your guidance, we will finally extinguish the 'T-Rex' and move into a new era of governance.

Thank you for your support—let’s get to work.

The "T-Rex" Scenario: Why the fear of change is your greatest risk?

In the image below, I describe what I call the "Legacy Trap Mindset." It is the famous "T-Rex": an EDI ecosystem that no one wants to touch because "it has been working for 10 years."

The problem is that no one knows where the documentation is, how the transformations were built, or how to perform quick maintenance in case of an error. Within the context of Clean Core, keeping this dinosaur alive creates an innovation bottleneck.

Ownership Transfer: The consultant acts as an initial guide only. Long-term ownership of MIGs, MAGs, and TPM contracts must reside with the business team to ensure operational autonomy.

Image 1 - trap mindste legacy for B2B EDI

A SAP BTP Integration Suite - IA Perspective: Where does Integration Advisor truly fit?

Although IA is underutilized in the market, the hands-on mastery I have acquired by studying this tool in depth allows me to face this chaos with a clear strategy. If I were leading this migration today, my stance as an SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant would be structured on two pillars:

Enablement and Trust (The Human Factor)

I would provide a practical internal course to give confidence to the business team, B2B specialists, and SAP functional consultants. They need to understand that IA is not just another "IT tool," but a platform that returns mapping control to those who truly understand the business rules. It leverages Machine Learning and SAP’s Crowd Encyclopedia to accelerate what used to take weeks of manual coding.

Governance and Architecture (The Technical Factor)

This is where many fail: creating MIGs (Message Implementation Guidelines) and MAGs (Mapping Guidelines) in isolation only speeds up technical construction but doesn't solve the underlying disorder. My role would be:

  • Defining Semantics: Creating MIGs with real business meaning.
  • The "Canonical Path": Structuring the integration using a canonical model ( When two types of EDI message type are semantic with the respective message type from SAP side)
  • Materialization via TPM: Demonstrating how Trading Partner Management (TPM) must be used to materialize integration templates and contracts.

Without alignment between the contracts defined in TPM and the mappings in IA, the most valuable assets are lost: governance, traceability, and reusability. It is not about "copying and pasting" legacy logic, but using IA to clean the architecture—leaving SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) only with lightweight technical execution and lean iFlows.

“MIG and MAG build - TPM governs - Without TPM, there is no sustainable B2B integration.” 

Image 2 - SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant - Internal Enablement on SAP Integration Advisor.

References
  • SAP BTP Integration Advisor Demo
  • How to build custom B2B Interface using Integration Advisor , AS2 Adapters and API Proxy
  • Integration Advisor: Overview of components for building B2B integration content and further reading

A SAP BTP Integration Suite - IA Perspective: fit into MIGs?

The first step in killing the "T-Rex" is the correct construction of MIGs (Message Implementation Guidelines). As a consultant, my role is to guide the team at the base of the pyramid:

  • 1:1 Structure: Creating one object per Message Type (EDI or SAP), ensuring granularity.
  • Business Semantics: Going beyond the technical side by defining rules, field usage, and documenting Codelists.
  • Facilitation: Acting as the bridge that translates technical standards (EDIFACT/X12) into the actual requirements of the SAP process.

Responsibilities and Roles of the SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant - IA - MIG

What the IA Consultant DOES:

  • Facilitation: Teaches how to operate the IA and apply the correct semantics to fields.
  • Technical Oversight: Ensures the MIG follows the standard (1:1) and remains technically reusable.
  • Mentorship: Guides the documentation of codelists and qualifiers.

What the IA Consultant DOES NOT do:

  • Define Business Rules: The business decides what it needs; the consultant only shows where to implement it.
  • Data Governance: The consultant delivers the structure, but responsibility for the data itself lies with the process owner.
  • Flow Decisions: Does not interpret commercial rules without validation from Key Users.

“MIG defines clarity, semantics, and standards."

Image 3 - SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant - Providing guidance on where and how to create a MIG and select the message type.

References - MIG
  • Creating MIGs and MAGs Using Integration Advisor in SAP BTP Cockpit
  • integration content advisor: Create a customized interface using MIG editor
  • Integration Advisor – multi-payload support for MIG creation
  • Integration Advisor – direct support of EDI payloads
  • Creating MIGs and MAGs Using Integration Advisor in SAP BTP Cockpit
  • integration content advisor: Discover B2B/A2A standard libraries
  • Integration Advisor : Use of cXML Type System Exporting to CPI

A SAP BTP Integration Suite - IA Perspective: fit into MAG?

If the MIG is the definition of the object, the MAG (Mapping Guideline) is where the transformation magic happens. The consultant acts as the guide who materializes this connection.

What the Consultant DOES:

  • Connectivity: Guides the correct selection of Source and Target MIGs.
  • Targeted Mapping: Explains how to perform field-to-field mapping, ensuring that the semantics defined in the MIG are respected.
  • Conversion Logic: Implements and teaches how to use basic conversion functions to adjust data between standards (e.g., transforming date formats or units of measure).
  • Artifact Generation: Demonstrates how to generate the schemas (XSD) and transformations (XSLT) that the CPI will utilize.

What the Consultant DOES NOT do:

  • Define Complex Business Logic: The consultant implements the technical conversion, but calculation rules or commercial decisions must come from the functional side.
  • Map Without a Base: The consultant must not start a MAG if the MIGs have not been properly validated by the business.

“The MAG is not a technical mapping; it is an adapter between meaning and the platform.”

Image 4 - SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant - How to create a MAG from MIG outbound and MIG Inbound

References MAG
  • Integration Advisor: complex mapping code for dimension conversion in SAP B2B
  • Base-/Overlay Mappings for Integration Advisor
  • Integration Advisor – Download MAG Simulation Result as EDI Payload
  • Accessing Headers and Properties in Integration Advisor (IA) Mapping Guidelines (MAG) with the Global Parameters
  • Integration Advisor: Conditional Mapping Feature
  • Integration Advisor: Conditional mapping in MAG to pass one value from the multiple occurrence of an element, based on other element's value
  • Complex Mappings 
    • SAP MAG mapping many occurrence node to 1 occurrence node and take last occurrence values to target
    • SAP TPM MAG or IA MAG :choose or multiple if conditions
    • SAP TPM MAG conditional mapping target node it's child

Where does an SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant fit into TPM?

The SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant must guide and enforce the use of TPM (Trading Partner Management) as a true governance layer. To be honest, TPM is not a "ten-headed beast" or some unreachable diamond; however, the most critical part is the definition of Identifiers within the EDI envelopes. If these are configured incorrectly, the agreement will fail to trigger even if everything else is perfect. I will demonstrate this below.

What is NOT the responsibility of the (IA/TPM) Consultant

For a migration to be sustainable, the consultant must not take over tasks that belong to business management or day-to-day operations.

The Consultant DOES NOT:

  • Define Commercial Rules: Does not decide legal terms, freight conditions, or SLAs. The business defines the rule; the consultant only configures it.
  • Operational Execution (TPM): Is not responsible for the continuous registration of hundreds of partners, certificate maintenance, or agreement versioning once the project has stabilized.
  • Contract Negotiation: Does not act in the alignment of deadlines or contractual obligations with external suppliers and customers.

Summary: The consultant designs the architecture and the migration process. The operational life of the tool (onboarding new partners and business decisions) must be managed by the company's internal EDI specialist team.

“MIG defines the meaning, MAG defines the destination, TPM defines the contract.”

Image 5 - SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant - How to create a TPM

References
  • TPM Onboarding Demo
  • Use TPM, IA, CI to Efficiently Manage and Run Complex B2B Transactions
  • Bridging EDI and SAP S/4HANA Cloud: Seamless EDI-to-SOAP Integration

The Developer’s Playground: Where SAP CPI Experts Take Control

Now, we enter the territory where we, as SAP CPI experts, have total dominance.

Once all the steps above are completed—specifically once the TPM is configured and the Agreement is accepted and deployed—something critical happens behind the scenes.

These objects are sent to an internal repository within SAP BTP: the Trading Partner Table.

Those of us entrenched in the iFlows, this is where it gets interesting. This table is accessed via Groovy Scripts within the standard B2B iFlows. It is here that the runtime logic fetches the active agreements, identifiers, and mapping versions.

If you are a CPI developer, this is your moment to shine: understanding how the Agreement Dispatcher and the EDI Splitter interact with this internal BTP data is what separates a standard developer from a true Integration Suite Specialist.

We aren't just "connecting pipes" anymore; we are orchestrating a dynamic, metadata-driven engine.

Image 6 - SAP BTP Integration Suite Consultant - CPI Implementation

Technical Deep Dive: Standard Packages and the "Plain ID" Trap

I will now explain the possibilities and the path I took to streamline this integration. I am intentionally ignoring the option of building a fully manual, custom iFlow. Such an approach would be unnecessarily complex, time-consuming, and redundant given the standard packages available.

Standard EDI Package Options:

EDI Integration Templates for SAP Integration Advisor - A versatile set of iFlows for various scenarios.

Cloud Integration - Trading Partner Management V2- The complete governance suite.

The TPM V2 Workflow:

  • Step 1: Ingress (Generic, depends on the channel: HTTP, SFTP, SOAP, IDoc, ProcessDirect, AS2).
  • Step 1b: Persistency (Write Message to Message Queue).
  • Step 2: Interchange Processing Flow V2 (The "Brain").
  • Step 3: Receiver Communication Flow V2.

My Assessment: After debugging every step in both packages, the standalone EDI Integration Templates work perfectly if you have your MIGs and MAGs ready. However, you lose governance, traceability, and the centralized contract management that TPM provides. This standalone iFlow is only valid for small-scale integrations.

Image 6 - Inject Process MAG to SAP CPI Iflow

 

Image 7 - Injection Steps, Connection, Package, Iflow and bummm !

The "Isolation Test" Strategy: Validating the MAG

Before moving into the full TPM complexity, here is my technical recommendation: use the EDI Integration Template iFlow to validate your mapping as a whole.

How to do it:

  • Configure the Pre and Post-processing steps with your generated XSD and XSLT files.
  • Run a test using a Content Modifier with the raw EDI "N" format (in my case, an X12 850) as plain text.
  • It doesn’t matter if it’s EDI to IDoc or, as I tested, EDI to OData—the communication channel is secondary at this stage.

Pro-Tip: I used the standalone iFlow to validate my mapping (MAG) before moving to TPM, injecting the MAG directly into a copy of the standard iFlow and testing with a Content Modifier using plain text (X12 850), I could validate the logic instantly. This is crucial because if you try to debug the Step 2 - Interchange Processing Flow without a prior test, grab a coffee and bring plenty of patience and papers because you are going to cry as me.

Crucial Recommendation: Pay close attention to the Validate and Analyze EDI Interchange step configuration. I suggest mirroring the settings in Step 2 - Interchange Processing Flow V2 exactly.

Note on Testing: Please keep in mind that I am an expert in integration, not in business semantics or specific EDI file structures. Many of my test files were generated manually or extracted from internet, which caused significant issues during the validation phase. Aligning these configurations precisely was the only way I found to ensure stability and overcome those hurdles.

Image 8 - Validacao da MAG e verificado do EDI Splitter

The "Agreement Plain ID" Headache

Once everything is configured and the agreement is deployed in TPM, it generates a unique "Information Package" for the trading partner based on identifiers. This is where the Agreement Plain ID comes in the configuration of identifiers in the Company and Partners regards the exchange header validation.

Imagem 9 - Aggremment Active in TPM

After successfully completing these steps, you will generate the "Trading Partner Information Package." This process creates a unique identification string based on the company's and the partner's identifiers.

This object—the Agreement Plain ID—is exactly what caused me so much frustration during the implementation.

What does a string like SOAP-ASC-X12--004010-BUYERCO-ZZ----SAP-ZZ----850 actually mean? It is a concatenation of the identifiers found in the EDI header:

  • SOAP: Partner Sender Channel

  • ASC-X12--004010: Message Type

  • BUYERCO-ZZ: Partner Identifier

  • SAP-ZZ: Receiver Identifier

  • 850: Transaction Code (Orders)

The Trap: If these identifiers are registered incorrectly in Company and Partner sides —even by one character—the integration will fail. There is a Groovy script of nearly 1,000 lines inside the standard package that handles this logic. I had to debug it to understand why my agreement wasn't being found.

Forced error: ISA*00*...*ZZ*BUYERCO*ZZ*SAP2... (The "SAP2" mismatch prevents the iFlow from finding the Agreement in the TPM table).

 
Imagem 10 - Bug between Partner Agremment ID and the header detail of the message as EDI or SAP Message Type

Crucial: Number Range Synchronization Ensure the Number Range is identically named in the TPM Company/Partner, the Agreement, and the SAP CPI Number Range monitor. Failure to align these exactly will trigger errors. I also experienced a platform bug where a locked Agreement prevented the deletion/update of the INC_UN_EDIFACT range.

 

Image 11 - Number Range

 Pro Tip: Custom Number Ranges If a TPM Agreement gets stuck (e.g., locking INC_INB_EDIFACT), use a Custom Number Range. This bypasses platform bugs and is a best practice for high-volume scenarios to prevent duplicate sequence numbers across different partner agreements, remember that this was test with ODETTE EDIFACT 96A not with another scenario X12.

In the platform that I have access there is somehow to agreements that was not delete 100% locking the INC_INB_EDIFACT, I have no idea how to delete or if must open SAP ticket for it:

 

Image 13 - Trading Agrement locking the INC_INB_EDIFACT.
SAP CPI Iflow - Step 2 - Interchange Processing Flow V2 - for SAP TPM - SAP Integration Advisor and always failed in this step:

 

Image 12 - Set Control Numers fails

Error: javax.script.ScriptException: java.lang.Exception: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Error reading number range ICN_UN_EDIFACT @ line 46 in setControlNumbers.groovy, cause: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Error reading number range ICN_UN_EDIFACT

I debugged another simple iFlow and it worked, so I still couldn't understand the cause of these locked records. I opened a thread on SAP SCN but received no response. I then tested a workaround—which I do not recommend—that involved modifying the standard CPI iFlow in Step 2, though I later reverted it to the original version.

Image 13 - Workaround Iflow to check outside TPM config the number range ICN_UN_EDIFACT 

 

Image 14 - Workaround Iflow to check outside TPM lock range number INC_UNB_EDIFACT

Inside the Step 2 - Interchange Processing Flow, there is a Local Integration Process for mapping. Since MAGs are based on XSLT and have some limitations, you can use ProcessDirect to call PRE and POST processing flows for complex logic or fine-tuning.

Image 15 - Local Integration Process - PRO and POS mapping processing

Now, let’s look at the "perfect scenario"—everything built, configured, and ready for action. In this case, I decided to push the limits: I used Scenario 1 with a SOAP call executing an EDI Flat File via a SOAP envelope.

The result? Don't worry about Step 5; I am simply looping the message back into the CPI for processing.

Imagem 16 - Full processing
 

The Million-Dollar Question: What is Stopping the Evolution?

If the technical solution is ready and the Clean Core strategy is the goal, why are so many companies still feeding the "EDI-T-Rex"?

The barrier isn't the technology—it’s the mindset and the perceived risk of disturbing a "working" (albeit broken) giant.

To turn the engine on, we need to address the elephant in the room:

  • Stakeholder Alignment: Success requires a unified front. Project Managers and Architects must stop viewing EDI as a "legacy chore" and start seeing it as a strategic business asset.
  • The Cost of Fear: We keep the T-Rex alive because it controls critical processes. But "feeding" it—through manual mapping, undocumented iFlows, and constant troubleshooting—is draining budgets that should be fueling innovation.
  • Internal Capability: Transitioning requires moving from "manual coding" to "intelligent curation" using the SAP Integration Advisor.

The ROI of Killing the T-Rex

Transitioning to a Modern B2B Engine isn't just a technical upgrade; it’s a financial imperative:

  • Reduced Development Time: Using the Integration Advisor can reduce mapping efforts by up to 60-80% through crowdsourced templates.
  • Lower Maintenance Costs: Decoupling custom logic from the core means fewer breakages during SAP upgrades.
  • Business Agility: Onboard new partners in days, not months, directly impacting your time-to-market.

Stop Guessing, Start Proving

The roadmap is right in front of you. You don’t have to replace everything at once. The most viable path is a low-risk POC (Proof of Concept). Pick a single, non-critical flow, apply the Integration Advisor methodology, and witness the efficiency firsthand. Once the value is proven, you can execute a robust, confident migration.

Industrialized Automation vs. Manual Labor

For large-scale EDI migrations, these tools replace the manual effort of "retyping" hundreds of flows with industrial automation. Instead of analysts manually configuring every partner, we extract definitions from legacy systems and convert them into TPM entries and iFlows, reducing months of development into weeks of configuration.

The most strategic advantage is validation without external partner involvement. By capturing real messages from the current environment and running them through the new system, we can perform an automatic comparison. This ensures the EDI mapping is 100% faithful to the original, eliminating human error and the need for exhaustive manual testing with every vendor.

In short, these solutions transform migration into a process of governance and audit, rather than error-prone manual development. This ensures predictable timelines and prevents supply chain disruptions, making massive projects feasible with a lean team.

  • Int4 Shield (formerly IFTT):
    • Int4 Shield - Migration to SAP Integration Suite
    • SAP News - Test Automation for SAP Integration Suite
    • SAP Store - Advanced Business Process Testing
